title: RuntimeError: restricted attribute setting __doc__ when being imported in python2.7 in a restricted frame
body:
Hi!
I'm writing a python program where I need to hook up the `__import__` function in certain modules‘ `__builtins__` dict to do some stuff, so that I can manage the imports in a way meta path hooks cannot provide.
In python3+ it works just fine, but in python2.7 the interpreter I got this error
```
  File "six.py", line 625, in <module>
    get_unbound_function, """Get the function out of a possibly unbound function"""
  File "six.py", line 82, in _add_doc
    func.__doc__ = doc
RuntimeError: restricted attribute
```
It turns out the python 2.7 interpreter does not allow changing function object's `__doc__` attribute in a restricted frame, which is defined by the frame's `__builtins__` reference is not pointing to the internal one.

here is a repro script
```
#! /usr/bin/python2.7

import imp
import sys
import os

name = 'six'
dir_name = os.getcwd()  # where six.py lives

def my_import(name, globals, locals, fromlist, level):
    print(name, fromlist, level)
    return __import__(name, globals, locals, fromlist, level)

spec = imp.find_module(name, [dir_name])
module = imp.new_module(name)
my_builtins = dict(__builtins__.__dict__)
my_builtins['__import__'] = my_import
module.__builtins__ = my_builtins
sys.modules[name] = module
imp.load_module(name, *spec)

```
Thanks!

title: Fix `UserDict` move in Python2
body:
# Background

The current implementation of `UserDict` attribute maps `UserDict.UserDict` to `collections.UserDict`:
```python
MovedAttribute("UserDict", "UserDict", "collections"),
```

From the Python 2.7 [documentation](https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/userdict.html#module-UserList):
> For backward compatibility, instances of `UserDict` are not iterable.

This limitation does not exist in Python3.
As a result, `six` introduces a bug in Python2.


## Reproduction steps:
```python
from six.moves import UserDict

d = UserDict({'key': 'output'})
for k in d:
    print(d[k])
```

`PY3` output:
```
output
```

`PY2` output:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/bxsx/.pyenv/versions/2.7.18/lib/python2.7/UserDict.py", line 40, in __getitem__
    raise KeyError(key)
KeyError: 0
```

# Solution
This PR addresses it by updating `UserDict` attribute to map`UserDict.IterableUserDict` in Python2 and  `collections.UserDict` in Python3.
PR also adds moves for `IterableUserDict` which maps to the same attribute as `UserDict`.

PR fixes #281 issue

title: Fix the `UserDict` move on Python2
body:
# Background

The current implementation of the `UserDict` attribute maps `UserDict.UserDict` to `collections.UserDict`:
```python
MovedAttribute("UserDict", "UserDict", "collections"),
```

From the Python 2.7 [documentation](https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/userdict.html#module-UserList):
> For backward compatibility, instances of `UserDict` are not iterable.

This limitation does not exist in Python3.
As a result, `six` introduces a bug in Python2.


## Reproduction steps:
```python
from six.moves import UserDict

d = UserDict({'key': 'output'})
for k in d:
    print(d[k])
```

`PY3` output:
```
output
```

`PY2` output:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/bxsx/.pyenv/versions/2.7.18/lib/python2.7/UserDict.py", line 40, in __getitem__
    raise KeyError(key)
KeyError: 0
```

# Solution
This PR addresses it by updating the `UserDict` attribute to map`UserDict.IterableUserDict` on Python 2 and  `collections.UserDict` on Python3.
The PR also adds the moved attribute `IterableUserDict` which maps to the same attributes as `UserDict`.

The PR fixes #281 issue

title: Json exception
body: The Python3 json module raises JSONDecodeError where the Python2 json module raises ValueError. Added six.JSONDecodeError that can be used to catch the exception regardless of version.

title: Add six.moves.unittest_mock
body:
Unittests mock module was added in python 3, it's called `unittest.mock` in python 3 but it was made available as a backport for python 2 via pypi as `mock`. 

The information is listed on the python 3 documentation https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.mock.html

> unittest.mock — mock object library
> New in version 3.3.
> Source code: Lib/unittest/mock.py
...
> There is a backport of unittest.mock for earlier versions of Python, available as mock on PyPI.

Mock on pypi: https://pypi.org/project/mock/

This lets a user write `six.moves.unittest_mock` which is handy for projects like mine that use mock on python 2 and 3.

Hope this PR is alright. I also updated the changes file and version number etc, as it seemed the right thing to do.

title: New utility: is_bound_method
body:
The behaviour of `inspect.ismethod` is inconsistent between Python 3 and 2. In Python 3, it returns `True` only for bound methods (since there's no way to tell whether a function object is an unbound method), while in Python 2 it returns `True` for both bound and unbound.

This PR adds an `is_bound_method` utility which returns `True` iff the object is callable and is a bound method (either instance- or class-).

Also added tests for this.

title: provide provide a decorator to alias keyword kwargs into `_` suffix alternatives
body:
provide a decorator to alias keyword kwargs into `_` suffix alternatives

```python
@six.pep492
def task1(ham, async_): return async_

@six.pep492
def task2(ham, await_): return await_
```


so that
```python
ob = object()
assert (
    ob
    is task1(async=ob)
    is task1(ob)
    is task1(async_=ob)
    is task2(await=ob)
    is task2(ob)
    is task2(await_=ob)
)
```

See also https://github.com/jreese/fissix/issues/15

title: six.iterbytes name collision with (deferred) PEP 0467
body:
There's a [proposal (PEP 0467)](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0467/#addition-of-optimised-iterator-methods-that-produce-bytes-objects
) to add a bytes.iterbytes method, that currently does the opposite of six.iterbytes

```python
>>> tuple(b"ABC".iterbytes())
(b'A', b'B', b'C')
>>> tuple(six.iterbytes(b"ABC"))
(65, 66, 67)
```

in an ideal world I'd like to see:

```python
>>> tuple(six.iterbytes(b"ABC"))
(b'A', b'B', b'C')
>>> tuple(six.iterords(b"ABC"))
(65, 66, 67)
```

but that would require a major version change, as it's changing the existing six.iterbytes function

title: Optimize ensure_str and ensure_binary.
body:
We found that large applications that have undergone a 2 -> 3 migration
and wound up with a lot of six.ensure_str and six.ensure_binary calls
could save 1-2% CPU usage by optimizing these for the common case.

Further optimization could be done by replacing them with extension
module implementations - assumed out of scope for the pure Python six
project itself.

Ideally all of these calls and use of six in people's code would be
removed after there all need for any Python 2 compatibility is gone.
But completing that kind of type cleanup requires a lot of human
engineering time.  This lowers the ongoing costs in the interim.

Contributed by YouTube.

title: add six.html_escape() due to removal of cgi.escape() in 3.8
body:
Closes #159.

Note that this is not a simple move, since `cgi.escape()` has `False` rather than `True` as the default for the *quote* parameter, and it also doesn't quote single quote characters (`'`) when *quote* is True.

The tests are based on those for `html.escape` [in the CPython test suite](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/5c0c325453a175350e3c18ebb10cc10c37f9595c/Lib/test/test_html.py).

title: Add support for PEP 560
body:
This is mostly important for `typing` module that is extensively using PEP 560 since Python 3.7. The goal of this PR is to make
```python
class G(six.with_metaclass(ABCMeta, Generic[T])):
    ...
```
behave equivalently to
```python
class G(Generic[T], metaclass=ABCMeta):
    ...
```
and
```python
class G(Generic[T]):
    __metaclass__ = ABCMeta
```
on all Python versions (also with custom metaclasses on Python versions where it is supported).

title: Revert "Remove distutils fallback and outdated comment (#269)"
body:
This reverts commit d5efa74e2dfde8d4ddba13e127cd85c687e6016b.

The original intention of providing a distutils fallback has not gone away. These three extra lines will almost never be used, as most people have setuptools or install with pip anyway, and at the same time it serves as a very low-maintenance solution for people who *do* want to bootstrap setuptools.

Bootstrapping setuptools without vendored six (and pyparsing) is a valid use case. Although setuptools by default ships with vendored dependencies, it supports removing the contents of the _vendored/ directory and falling back to an installed version of six.py -- and thirdparty vendors of setuptools, such as Arch Linux and OpenSUSE, actually make use of this and need to be able to bootstrap the dependency tree of setuptools itself.

@jaraco @jdufresne

See also https://github.com/pyparsing/pyparsing/pull/133

title: Fix for Python 4
body:
We don't yet know if 3.10 or 4.0 will follow Python 3.9, but it will probably happen in [2020 when Python 3.9 reaches beta](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0596/#schedule) and as six is vendored and used in many codebases, it would be good for six to be ready for both.

There's several places in the codebase which essentially do:

```python
if sys.version_info[0] == 3:
   pass  # Python 3+ stuff
else:
   pass  # Python 2 stuff
```

When run on Python 4, this will run the Python 2 code!

This PR flips it around:

```python
if sys.version_info[0] == 2:
   pass  # Python 2 stuff
else:
   pass  # Python 3+ stuff
```

Thanks to @asottile for [flake8-2020](https://github.com/asottile/flake8-2020).

---

As an aside, there's a slight inconsistency here:

```python
# Useful for very coarse version differentiation.
PY2 = sys.version_info[0] == 2
PY3 = sys.version_info[0] == 3
PY34 = sys.version_info[0:2] >= (3, 4)
```

`PY34` is true on Python 4, but `PY3` is not. Would it be too big a break to change it?

```diff
-PY3 = sys.version_info[0] == 3
+PY3 = sys.version_info[0] >= 3
```

title: Add various string conversion utilities
body:
Currently six provides `ensure_str`, `ensure_text`, and `ensure_binary`. Typically these are used when you have a `str` object and want to convert to text or bytes, or the inverse.

I'd prefer to be explicit about which conversion I'm doing. For example, using `six.ensure_binary` should probably not be accepting text in py2 and should not be accepting binary in py3 (for most use cases). Effectively these equivalents make the code a little stricter about what types are actually expected.

They should also be more performant as they avoid an `isinstance` lookup on every conversion.

title: Add number_types
body:
There is already `integer_types` which purpose is to abstract away `long` which exists only in python2.

So, if I have code `isinstance(value, six.integer_types)`, that will work for integers. However, if I wanted to test for any number I would have to write `isinstance(value, six.integer_types + (float,))` for instance, which is ugly.

Request: add `number_types` that supports any real number
```
try:
    number_types = (int, long, float)

except NameError:
    number_types = (int, float)
```

so then one can write `isinstance(value, six.number_types)`.

title: add_metaclass: breaks super() without args
body:
Using the `six.add_metaclass` decorator breaks usage of `super()` without args in Python 3:

```python
import six

class Base():
    def method(self):
        print("Base.method")

class Meta(type):
    pass

# works:
# class C(Base, metaclass=Meta):
@six.add_metaclass(Meta)
class C(Base):
    def method(self):
        super().method()


C().method()
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "t-six.py", line 18, in <module>
    C().method()
  File "t-six.py", line 15, in method
    super().method()
TypeError: super(type, obj): obj must be an instance or subtype of type
```

As a workaround `super(C, self)` can be used.

title: Consider adding six.fspath
body:
Hi.

Python 3.6 has `os.fspath` which is supposed to be the standard way to get a file path from a PathLike object, e.g., file objects.
https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html?highlight=os%20fspath#os.fspath

In Python 2 and earlier Python 3s, the way to do it is `file_obj.name`.

Request: add `fspath` and `PathLike` to `six.py`. There is an official implementation that could be copied:
https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/os.py#L1025

title: assertNotRegexpMatches -> assertNotRegex?
body:
Python 3.5 deprecated `assertNotRegexpMatches` in favor of `assertNotRegex`  ( see https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html#unittest.TestCase.assertNotRegex ).  

Looking at the history of releases, it seems like it was omitted from the initial deprecation as a mistake then backported

* https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/1536
* https://bugs.python.org/issue30335

Right now `assertNotRegexpMatches` works in both Py2 and Py3, but that is scheduled to change. Any chance six can have a `assertNotRegex` sooner than later?

title: Rationale for `reraise` choice: `value` unset in PY3 but not PY2?
body:
Along with my [other question](https://github.com/benjaminp/six/issues/278) I'm having trouble understanding why `value = None` is being done only in Python 3 and not in Python 2? Wouldn't it be safer against reference cycles to just wipe them all out, just in case?

Is it because in Python 3 we know that `value` **for sure will** hold a reference to `tb`, while in Python 2 `value` **probably does not** hold a reference to `tb`?

That's what I've been able to think of on my own, because in Python 2 the calling code would have to go out of its way to create a reference cycle with `value`, while in Python 3 the calling code could do everything right and still get a reference cycle, so `reraise` is just protecting against the cases that calling code cannot protect itself from?

I guess also my intuition is that it would be most resilient against reference cycles (even pathological ones where the calling code did something really wrong) to just `tp = value = tb = None` in all cases in the `finally` - not saying that this is what you should do, just trying to understand if I am wrong about that, or if there is any other rationale I'm missing?

title: Rationale for `reraise` choice: `tb = None` instead of `del tb`?
body:
I don't see this documented anywhere, and I'm just trying to understand:

What's the reason for preferring `tb = None` instead of `del tb` in the implementation of `reraise`?

title: import six.moves.http_client locks interpreter
body:
When importing ``six.moves.http_client`` within a script my interpreter freezes up. I don't get the same behaviour when importing in the REPL:

```
$ python       
Python 3.6.6 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Jun 28 2018, 17:14:51) 
[GCC 7.2.0] on linux
...
>>> import six.moves.http_client
>>> 
```

```
$ cat foo.py
import six
print('Six version: ', six.__version__)
import six.moves.http_client
print('six.moves.http_client')

$ python foo.py
Six version:  1.11.0
...
<wait a very long time and then KeyboardInterrupt to get some traceback>
...
^CTraceback (most recent call last):
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 888, in _find_spec
AttributeError: '_SixMetaPathImporter' object has no attribute 'find_spec'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "foo.sh", line 3, in <module>
    import six.moves.http_client
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 971, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 951, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 890, in _find_spec
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 867, in _find_spec_legacy
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 449, in spec_from_loader
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/six.py", line 216, in is_package
    return hasattr(self.__get_module(fullname), "__path__")
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/six.py", line 118, in __getattr__
    _module = self._resolve()
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/six.py", line 115, in _resolve
    return _import_module(self.mod)
  File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/six.py", line 82, in _import_module
    __import__(name)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 202, in _lock_unlock_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 98, in acquire
KeyboardInterrupt
```

Changing the import to ``from six.moves import http_client`` results in the import working fine. I'm on a RHEL6 machine, but using the Anaconda distribution (hence the modern GCC compiler). I tried the same on my mac and couldn't reproduce the issue.


This might seem esoteric, but I've traced this back from ``urllib3`` which itself I traced from ``requests``. [The line that makes this import call is in ``urllibr3.exceptions``](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/master/src/urllib3/exceptions.py#L2). I'll submit a PR against urllib3 for this, but wanted to raise this here - I guess it is not expected behaviour, and worth sharing.

title: six.add_metaclass does not preserve __qualname__ for nested classes
body:
Using `six.add_metaclass` on a nested class loses the original class's `__qualname__` on Python 3:

```python
>>> from six import add_metaclass
>>> class A:
...     class B:
...         pass
...
>>> A.B
<class '__main__.A.B'>
>>> class MyMeta(type): pass
...
>>> class A:
...     @add_metaclass(MyMeta)
...     class B:
...         pass
...
>>> A.B
<class '__main__.B'>
```

title: with_metaclass: check existence of `__prepare__` attribute before calling it
body:
https://github.com/prettier/plugin-python/blob/04dc40a40501a13eaec5fcb4d5c99829a31d3ffc/vendor/python/six.py#L831

The `def with_metaclass()` implementation assumes that all meta classes have `__prepare__` defined. 

The Python Reference says (https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#preparing-the-class-namespace):

> If the metaclass has a `__prepare__` attribute, it is called as [...].
> 
> If the metaclass has no `__prepare__` attribute, then the class namespace is initialised as an empty ordered mapping.

Therefore, I think `six` should check existence of `__prepare__` attribute before calling it, as `__prepare__` is not defined on `type` in PY2.

title: six.wraps doesn't ignore non-existing attributes like Python 3 does
body:
Here's a repro script that fails in Python 2, but works in Python 3:
```python
import six
class Hello(object):
    def __call__(self):
        return "Hello"
f = Hello()
@six.wraps(f)
def world():
    return f() + ", world"
```

On Python 2 it fails with 
```
AttributeError: 'Hello' object has no attribute '__name__'
```
On Python 3 it succeeeds, because it was fixed in in https://bugs.python.org/issue3445. Given the trivial implementation it should be enough to backport the [update_wrapper](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/445f1b35ce8461268438c8a6b327ddc764287e05/Lib/functools.py#L37-L65) function as-is.

title: Provide functions that allow the dictionary to be used more efficiently.
body:
## Problem
Sometimes it is not possible to provide code in python 2 and python 3 without any performance losses.
The dictionary functions `.keys()`, `items()`, `values()` used to return a `list`, but now they return a `view`.

E.g.:
``` 
list(d.keys())
list(d.items())
list(d.values()) 
```

This would work in python 2 and python 3 but it is not efficient.
In python 2 it copies the memory into a new list instead of using the existing list.

## Solution
Defining a function which provides a list in python 2 and python 3 without performance losses.
E.g.:
```
d.keys() -> six.listkeys(d)
d.items() -> six.listitems(d)
d.values() -> six.listvalues(d)
```

title: indexbytes needs to be fixed for py3
body:
six.indexbytes returns int in all cases for Py2 whereas returns byte for list of byte in Py3. This is because six is using getitem internally which will not work for list of byte strings. In Py2, we use ord(buf[i]) which will return an int. 

```python
six.indexbytes([b'u'],0)                                                                           
PY3;  b'u'
PY2;  117
```

title: six.reraise should not ignore exception type
body:
As we can see, [six.reraise](https://github.com/benjaminp/six/blob/master/six.py#L693) just **ignore** the exception type in Python 3.
ps: it works correctly in Python 2.

Q: Why not use `six.raise_from` in following example?    
A: `six.raise_from` will lose traceback info in Python 2.

For example::
```python
import sys
import six


class CustomException(Exception):
    pass


try:
    try:
        raise RuntimeError('hello world')
    except Exception as e:
        t, v, tb = sys.exc_info()

        six.reraise(CustomException, v, tb)
        #raise CustomException, v, tb  # Python 2
        #raise CustomException(e).with_traceback(tb)  # Python 3
except Exception as e:
    # ------------------NOTICE------------------
    # t SHOULD be CustomException, but it is RuntimeError in Python 3
    # ------------------NOTICE------------------
    t, v, tb = sys.exc_info()
    raise
```

Python 3 output::
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

title: eventlet/eventlet#480: use importlib.import_module, not __import__()
body:
Libraries using `six.MovedModule` or `six.MovedAttribute` presently do not honor [PEP 302](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0302/) import hooks because `__import__()` doesn't support them. (See https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/480)

Using `importlib.import_module()` allows removing the `six._import_module()` function, whose purpose is to map `__import__()` functionality to what `importlib.import_module()` already provides.

There seems to be a problem with the usage of urllib.parse through six and how pylint handles it. Take the following example:

```python
urlparse.urlunparse(
```

title: pickle protocol
body:
It seems as though it would be helpful to modify the `pickle.dump(s)` methods to use `protocol=HIGHEST_PROTOCOL`, as this would be consistent with Python3 and should be functional in Python2.6+ (stated functionality of six).

The default Python2 protocol is 0, which require `__getstate__` and `__setstate__` methods; however Python 3 uses `protocol=HIGEST_PROTCOL` ([equivalent to 4 since Python 3.4](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html#data-stream-format)).

Manipulating the `dump(s)` methods to use the highest protocol would allow someone to write the most "slim" code that will work in both Python2 and Python3.

title: add_metaclass fails with name-mangled slots
body:
The `add_metalclass` decorator assumes that [all members of `__slots__` will be exposed in the class `__dict__`](https://github.com/benjaminp/six/blob/63b2661b94463b59752396a3562c9e5ebe672f97/six.py#L844), but this isn't true for name-mangled slots (those having at least two leading underscores and at most one trailing underscore). Example:

```python
import six

class Meta(type):
    pass

@six.add_metaclass(Meta)
class Foo(object):
    __slots__ = (
        'something',
        '_something',
        '__something'
    )
```

Running this gives the error:

```
$ python bug.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bug.py", line 7, in <module>
    class Foo(object):
  File "/home/apearce/tmp/six-bug/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/six.py", line 844, in wrapper
    orig_vars.pop(slots_var)
KeyError: '__something'
```

This is because the `__something` slot is given the key `_Foo__something` key in `__dict__`, not `__something`.

## Workarounds

Using `with_metaclass` works.

```python
import six

class Meta(type):
    pass

class Some(six.with_metaclass(Meta, object)):
    __slots__ = (
        'something',
        '_something',
        '__something'
    )
```

## Solutions

One way around this would be to detect if name mangling will happen.

```python
def _mangled_name(cls, name):
    """Return the mangled version of name belonging to cls, if appropriate.

    Python applies name mangling if the name starts with at least two
    underscores and ends with at most one underscore.
    """
    mangled = name.startswith('__') and not name.endswith('__')
    if mangled:
        name = '_{0}{1}'.format(cls.__name__, name)
    return name


def add_metaclass(metaclass):
    """Class decorator for creating a class with a metaclass."""
    def wrapper(cls):
        orig_vars = cls.__dict__.copy()
        slots = orig_vars.get('__slots__')
        if slots is not None:
            if isinstance(slots, str):
                slots = [slots]
            for slots_var in slots:
                orig_vars.pop(_mangled_name(cls, slots_var))
        orig_vars.pop('__dict__', None)
        orig_vars.pop('__weakref__', None)
        return metaclass(cls.__name__, cls.__bases__, orig_vars)
    return wrapper
```

I'd open an MR with this, but am not sure if this is the ideal solution.

title: urllib uses different encodings in Python2 and Python3
body:
Example:
import six.moves.urllib
In Python2:
    urllib.parse.quote('\xf7')
    Output:'%F7'

In Python3:
    urllib.parse.quote('\xf7')
    Output:'%C3%B7'

The reason is probably that in Python2 raw string (bytes) is used, and in Python3 the string is encoded in UTF-8. This doesn't make sense for a library trying to provide the same behavior for both Python2 and Python3.

IMO the library should always use the raw string, since we always have the option to UTF-8 encode bytes manually.

title: Add ``python_2_bool_compatible``
body:
Python 2 calls ``obj.__nonzero__`` when convert ``obj`` to bool,
Python 3 calls ``obj.__bool__``    when convert ``obj`` to bool.

Add ``python_2_bool_compatible``, which is a decorator that
defines ``__nonzero__`` method under Python 2.
Under Python 3 it does nothing.

Example

```python
>>> @six.python_2_bool_compatible
... class Klass(object):
...     def __bool__(self):
...         return False
>>> obj = Klass()
>>> bool(obj)
False
```

title: Add a compatibility shim for `commands.getstatusoutput`?
body:
`six` currently includes a not-yet-released change to add `six.moves` entries for `commands.getoutput` and `commands.getstatusoutput`: https://github.com/benjaminp/six/commit/e05c7253043647e37bdbc13038bff06334fac8cb

While this is correct for `commands.getoutput`,  `subprocess.getstatusoutput` unfortunately broke backwards compatibility with Python 2's `commands.getstatusoutput` back in 3.3.4 (see https://bugs.python.org/issue22635 for details), which means the Python 3 API needs a compatibility shim to shift the exit code left by 8 bits to get it back into the format produced by `os.wait()`: https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.wait

Accordingly, a backwards compatible `getstatusoutput` implementation on Py3 actually looks like this:

    def py2_getstatusoutput(cmd):
        status, output = subprocess.getstatusoutput(command)
        if os.name != 'nt':
            # convert status to be interpreted according to the wait() rules
            status = status << 8
        return status, output

I'm not sure how to incorporate that into the `six.moves` structure, though :(

title: Feature Request: Error object compatibility
body:
When working with Python 2.7 and 3.6, I found that the object that is returned from an error being caught has changed.

For example:
```
try:
   import nonexistent_module
except ImportError as e:
   print(dir(e))
```
The outputs are:
Python 2.7
```
['__class__', '__delattr__', '__dict__', '__doc__', '__format__', '__getattribute__', '__getitem__', '__getslice__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__new__', '__reduce__', '__reduce_ex__', '__repr__', '__setattr__', '__setstate__', '__sizeof__', '__str__', '__subclasshook__', '__unicode__', 'args', 'message']
```
Python 3.6
```
['__cause__', '__class__', '__context__', '__delattr__', '__dict__', '__dir__', '__doc__', '__eq__', '__format__', '__ge__', '__getattribute__', '__gt__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__init_subclass__', '__le__', '__lt__', '__ne__', '__new__', '__reduce__', '__reduce_ex__', '__repr__', '__setattr__', '__setstate__', '__sizeof__', '__str__', '__subclasshook__', '__suppress_context__', '__traceback__', 'args', 'msg', 'name', 'path', 'with_traceback']
```

As can be seen, some stuff has changed.
Python 2.7
```
>>> e
>>> ImportError('No module named nonexistent_module')
>>> type(e)
>>> <type 'exceptions.ImportError'>
>>> e.args
>>> ('No module named nonexistent_module',)
>>> e.message
>>> 'No module named nonexistent_module' #  With a DeprecationWarning
```

Python 3.6
```
>>> e
>>> ModuleNotFoundError("No module named 'nonexistent_module'",)
>>> type(e)
>>> <class 'ModuleNotFoundError'>
>>> e.args
>>> ("No module named 'nonexistent_module'",)
>>> e.msg
>>> "No module named 'nonexistent_module'"
```
It would be nice if `six` could provide this object model compatibility.

title: Support for derived exceptions
body:
Hi, 
I've been using `six` on a daily basis in all of my Python projects, so first of all, thanks !

I have an enhancement proposal: it would be quite useful to be able to use `six` to differentiate builtin exceptions depending on the Python version: instead of using always the general exception to make sure it is compatible with any Python version, or to define an alias at the beginning of the program, six would make it possible to write:
```python
raise six.errors.FileNotFoundError("...")
```
to raise a `FileNotFoundError` on Python 3.3 and later, or an `OSError` on earlier versions.


Interesting candidates would be:
* `OSError` subclasses added in Python 3.3: `IsADirectoryError`, `PermissionError`, etc.
* `ModuleNotFoundError` added in Python 3.6
* `RecursionError`, added in Python 3.5

I think this would ease the forward compatibility of the code, allowing to raise more specific errors if available in the current Python version.

title: six.moves cannot be pickled with cloudpickle
body:
six.moves cannot be pickled with cloudpickle. Reproducer:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
from __future__ import absolute_import, division, print_function

import cloudpickle
import six.moves

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("cloudpickle version:", cloudpickle.__version__)
    print("six version:", six.__version__)
    cloudpickle.loads(cloudpickle.dumps(six.moves))
```

With Python version 2.7.11, cloudpickle version 0.2.2 and six version 1.10.0, this throws a RuntimeError with the message "maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object":

```
cloudpickle version: 0.2.2
six version: 1.10.0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 10, in <module>
    cloudpickle.loads(cloudpickle.dumps(six.moves))
  File "/opt/python/python-2.7/lib64/python2.7/pickle.py", line 1388, in loads
    return Unpickler(file).load()
  File "/opt/python/python-2.7/lib64/python2.7/pickle.py", line 864, in load
    dispatch[key](self)
  File "/opt/python/python-2.7/lib64/python2.7/pickle.py", line 1221, in load_build
    setstate = getattr(inst, "__setstate__", None)
  File "/usr/local/python/python-2.7/std/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py", line 118, in __getattr__
    _module = self._resolve()
  File "/usr/local/python/python-2.7/std/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py", line 115, in _resolve
    return _import_module(self.mod)
...
```

The reason for pickling six.moves is that a recent commit to cloudpickle changed it to pickle any modules that are used by functions, so pickling a function will also pickle any modules that it uses. For example, the bug is triggered by:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
from __future__ import absolute_import, division, print_function

import cloudpickle
import six.moves

def f():
    C = six.moves.http_cookies.SimpleCookie()
    return C

if __name__ == "__main__":
    cloudpickle.loads(cloudpickle.dumps(f))
```

I think the issue can be fixed by defining `_LazyModule.__reduce__`:

```python
def __reduce__(self):
    return _import_module, (self.__name__,)
```

title: Temporary metaclass should not inherit from "meta"
body:
In the current implementation of `with_metaclass`, the temporary `metaclass` inherits from `meta`. Later we call `type.__new__(metaclass, ...)`. This can lead to errors of the form
```
type.__new__(metaclass) is not safe, use ....__new__()
```
if `meta` is an extension type instead of a plain Python class.

Since I see no reason for inheriting from `meta`, this patch fixes that to inherit from the base class `type` instead.

title: setup.py imports six to get version, sometimes gets version of six used by setuptools
body:
Installing six from the six source distribution (sometimes) causes six's version to be determined incorrectly.  Setuptools now requires six, which means that when the setup script imports six, it (potentially) gets the six that setuptools requires, not the one included in the distribution.

When buildout tries to install a pinned version of six, the install fails. For example, it tries to install six 1.9 but when it runs the setup script, it installs it as 1.10, which fails, because the 1.10 is already installed.

If pip tries to install 1.9, the install succeeds.  If pip is asked to install a version before 1.6, the install fails, because pip places the new distribution in the path ahead of whatever version of six is used with setuptools and setuptools fails.

The difference is that when buildout runs setup, it puts it's own path before the distribution directory, while pip puts the distribution directory first.  If I hack the six 1.1 source release to set the version statically, I can install it with buildout. That wouldn't work for pip. 

The simplest solution would be to include the version in the setup script. Alternatively, you could just read it from six.py.

title: Define __prepare__() in with_metaclass()
body:
Define `__prepare__()` in `with_metaclass()`'s temporary
metaclass, and make sure that it passes the correct bases to the
real metaclass's `__prepare__()`.

The temporary metaclass previously didn't extend the
`__prepare__()` method, which meant that if the real metaclass
had a `__prepare__()`, it wouldn't get called correctly. This
could lead to bugs in Python 3 code.

The temporary metaclass's `__prepare__()` gets called with
```bases=(temporary_class,)```.  Since there was no proxy in the
middle, that was getting passed directly to the real metaclass's
`__prepare__()`. But then, if the real class's `__prepare__()`
method depended on the bases, the logic would be incorrect.

This was a problem in projects that use `enum` / `enum34` and
try to use `with_metaclass(EnumMeta)`. `enum34.EnumMeta` doesn't
define `__prepare__()`, since it is a Python 2 backport. Python
3's `enum.EnumMeta` does define `__prepare__()`, but originally
didn't depend at all on the bases. But starting in Python 3.6,
`enum.EnumMeta.__prepare__()` will raise `TypeError` if the
bases aren't valid for an enum subclass. Thus, a codebase that
was successfully using `enum` / `enum34` and
`with_metaclass(EnumMeta)` could break on Python 3.6.

title: ImportError raised from the MovedModule.__getattr__ method
body:
Hello,

Here's some minor bug I encounted while I wasn't explicitely using the `six` package. The description is pretty long and uninteresting but it offers steps to reproduce the issue. A clearer (?) explanation is provided afterwards.

**Raw description and code sample**

I've add the following error:

```
E
======================================================================
ERROR: bug (unittest2.loader._FailedTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
ImportError: Failed to import test module: bug
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/tkinter/__init__.py", line 36, in <module>
    import _tkinter
ImportError: No module named '_tkinter'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/some_path/my_new_env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 456, in _find_test_path
    module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
  File "/some_path/my_new_env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 395, in _get_module_from_name
    __import__(name)
  File "/home/josay/Geekage/six_bugs/bug.py", line 8, in <module>
    hasattr(o, 'toto')
  File "/some_path/my_new_env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/six.py", line 117, in __getattr__
    _module = self._resolve()
  File "/some_path/my_new_env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/six.py", line 114, in _resolve
    return _import_module(self.mod)
  File "/some_path/my_new_env/lib/python3.5/site-packages/six.py", line 81, in _import_module
    __import__(name)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/tkinter/__init__.py", line 38, in <module>
    raise ImportError(str(msg) + ', please install the python3-tk package')
ImportError: No module named '_tkinter', please install the python3-tk package
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.001s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

runnning the following command

`python -m unittest2 discover --start-directory=. --pattern=*.py`

in a Python 3.5 virtual env on the following code:

```
import gc
objs = gc.get_objects()
for o in objs:
    hasattr(o, 'toto')
```

(Using unittest2 is required to ensure that `six` gets somehow loaded automatically. Just running the code directly leads to no error.)

**Details**

The `MovedModule.__getattr__` method may raise an ImportError .

**Expectation**

From https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__getattr__ : 

> Called when an attribute lookup has not found the attribute in the usual places (i.e. it is not an instance attribute nor is it found in the class tree for self). name is the attribute name. This method should return the (computed) attribute value or raise an AttributeError exception.

Thus, I'd expect an AttributeError to be raised when the import in __getattr__ fails. Then it would be caught by `hasattr` or `getattr` with a default value.

**Potential fix**

Rewriting the method likes this seems to fix the problem:

```
   def __getattr__(self, attr):
        try:
            _module = self._resolve()
        except ImportError:
            raise AttributeError("ImportError during __getattr__")
        value = getattr(_module, attr)
        setattr(self, attr, value)
        return value

```
I'm happy to submit a pull-request if you think it makes sense.

title: Add moves for getoutput and getstatusoutput.
body:
(Moved from [pull request 84](https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/pull-requests/84/add-getstatusoutput-and-getoutput-to/diff) on bitbucket.)

Fixes #138 ("Six doesn't provide a solution for the commands module") by adding `commands.getoutput` and `commands.getstatusoutput` to `six.moves`.  I didn't move commands.getstatus, since it seems to have been removed entirely. Its behavior can be easily simulated using either by using subprocess.Popen or by ignoring the status from getstatusoutput, so I don't think leaving it out is a big deal. 

Also fixes #46. I think the proposal in https://github.com/benjaminp/six/issues/46#issuecomment-270032574 to use `subprocess.check_output` isn't ideal, since that can raise an exception on a nonzero exit status, and swallow `stdout`.

I updated the documentation to include it in the moves table. The diff looks big, since I needed to expand the third column to fit the long name of `subprocess.getstatusoutput`, but the only significant changes were to add these two rows.

I also added tests verifying that the the moves are able to execute commands and get their status. I've only tested them on OS X, but I'd expect it to work on Linux (just calls "echo") and possibly on Windows (though I can't test that).

Thanks so much for writing six! This library is super useful, and has really helped move Python 3 adoption forward!

title: Match Python 3 metaclass syntax
body:
Originally reported by: **Evan (Bitbucket: [evan_](https://bitbucket.org/evan_), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

The current signature of `with_metaclass` is awkward in that it puts the metaclass before the bases, whereas declaring classes naturally in Python 3 puts the metaclass last as a keyword-only argument, e.g. `class Class(base1, base2, metaclass=meta)`. Keyword-only arguments aren't supported by Python 2, but they can be faked by accepting `**kwargs` and doing a bit of filtering.

There are two ways of implementing this without breaking backwards compatibility:

1. Update `with_metaclass` to handle both ways of passing arguments, falling back to the original signature if `metaclass` is not given as a keyword argument. This is the simplest, but people unfamiliar with keyword-only arguments may assume from the signature `with_metaclass(*bases, metaclass)` that they are able to do `with_metaclass(base1, base2, meta)`, which will end up using `base1` as the metaclass with no warning.

2. Create another function which is a simple wrapper around `with_metaclass`. This function could mimic a real keyword-only argument, in which case `other_function(base1, base2, meta)` would raise a `TypeError`. This could optionally also involve deprecating `with_metaclass`.

Thoughts? Happy to do a PR to implement this.

title: six.hasattr()? Behaving like Python 3 - not swallowing _all_ exceptions
body:
Originally reported by: **Alex Willmer (Bitbucket: [moreati](https://bitbucket.org/moreati), GitHub: [moreati](https://github.com/moreati))**

----------------------------------------

Would a function that backports `hasattr()` from Python 3 to Python 2 be appropriate?

On Python 2 `hasattr()` masks *any* exception, whereas on Python 3 it only masks `AttributeError`.

More info: [hasattr() a dangerous misnomer](https://hynek.me/articles/hasattr/)
Existing implementation: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/hasattr-safe

If you're interested I'll prepare a PR.

title: six.BytesIO doesn't match io.BytesIO
body:
Originally reported by: **Stephen Lowrie (Bitbucket: [arithx](https://bitbucket.org/arithx), GitHub: [arithx](https://github.com/arithx))**

----------------------------------------

Currently six.BytesIO is a copy of six.StringIO.

When trying to pass a six.BytesIO instance into an io.BufferedReader instance it fails with the error: "AttributeError: StringIO instance has no attribute 'readable'".

Code example of the error:
  bytes_ = six.BytesIO()
  with open(file, 'rb') as stream:
    bytes_.write(str(stream.read()))
  bytes_.seek(0)
  wrapper = io.TextIOWrapper(io.BufferedReader(bytes_))

If you replace the six.BytesIO with io.BytesIO in Python 2 you don't get the error.

title: PY34 is defined inconsistently compared to PY2 and PY3
body:
Originally reported by: **astrofrog (Bitbucket: [astrofrog](https://bitbucket.org/astrofrog), GitHub: [astrofrog](https://github.com/astrofrog))**

----------------------------------------

The constant ``PY34`` is badly named: ``PY2`` means Python 2, ``PY3`` means Python 3, but ``PY34`` will be ``True`` for Python 3.6 or Python 4.3, which will read weirdly in code.

I would therefore propose renaming ``PY34`` to ``PY_GE_34``, and introducing a new variable ``PY_GE_3`` to mean ``sys.version_info[0] >= 3``.

title: format_map compatibility
body:
Originally reported by: **Guido van Rossum (Bitbucket: [gvanrossum](https://bitbucket.org/gvanrossum), GitHub: [gvanrossum](https://github.com/gvanrossum))**

----------------------------------------

I'd like to see six support `format_map()`. In PY3, `"...".format_map(d)` is almost but not quite the same as `"...".format(**d)` -- the difference only matters for things like default dict. The PY2 way of doing the same thing is apparently `string.Formatter().vformat("...", (), d)`.

title: string module methods moved
body:
Originally reported by: **Pedro Rodrigues (Bitbucket: [medecau](https://bitbucket.org/medecau), GitHub: [medecau](https://github.com/medecau))**

----------------------------------------

I have noticed that six does not "know" how to get maketrans() for both PY2 and PY3.
It moved as per the following documentation pages.

https://docs.python.org/2/library/string.html#string.maketrans
https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#bytes.maketrans
https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str.maketrans

It seems that other methods moved in a similar fashion.

*Sorry if this is not the best format for an issue or if it lacks information.*

title: six.moves.BytesFeedParser
body:
Originally reported by: **JocelynDelalande (Bitbucket: [JocelynDelalande](https://bitbucket.org/JocelynDelalande), GitHub: [JocelynDelalande](https://github.com/JocelynDelalande))**

----------------------------------------

In py2 there is only a email.feedparser.FeedParser

In py3 there is email.feedparser.FeedParser for unicode strings and [email.feedparser.BytesFeedParser](https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.parser.html?highlight=feedparser#email.parser.BytesFeedParser) for bytes.

So I suggest adding a `six.moves.BytesFeedParser` (or `six.FeedParser` ?) to offer  developper a consistent import path.

- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/issue/139

title: Six doesn't provide a solution for the commands module
body:
Originally reported by: **Anonymous**

----------------------------------------

Older versions of Python had the [commands module](https://docs.python.org/2/library/commands.html).  This was deprecated in 2.6 and removed in 3.0, with the methods being moved to subprocess.  Six should allow something like

```
#!python
from six.moves import commands

commands.getstatusoutput()
commands.getoutput()
commands.getstatus()
```

title: Please add per-file licenses
body:
Originally reported by: **petrcermak (Bitbucket: [petrcermak](https://bitbucket.org/petrcermak), GitHub: [petrcermak](https://github.com/petrcermak))**

----------------------------------------

_(Related to #129)_

The Chromium project (www.chromium.org) pulls in six indirectly through the catapult (https://github.com/catapult-project/catapult/) and gsutil (https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil) source repositories. In order for Chromium to be pulled into various Linux source distributions there's a requirement that all of the third party files pass the Linux licensecheck utility. Currently there are several files in the six repository missing per-file licenses. From a current run of licensecheck, they are:

```
$ licensecheck -r . | grep "No copyright"
./setup.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./test_six.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
```

We'd like to ask that per-file licenses be added to these files to make it easier to integrate six not only into Chromium, but also Linux distributions in general. Thanks.

- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/issue/131

title: range semantic differs between Py2/Py3
body:
Originally reported by: **Anonymous**

----------------------------------------

The problem here is that Py2's xrange is limited compared to Py3's. xrange only supports integers that fit in a C long while Py3's range doesn't have this limitation (since there's no difference between ints and longs anymore).

Simple test case:

On Python 2.7.10

```python
In [7]: six.moves.range(2**100, 2**101, 2**100)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OverflowError                             Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-c62711a06539> in <module>()
----> 1 six.moves.range(2**100, 2**101, 2**100)

OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C long
```

On Python 3.4.3

```Python
In [2]: six.moves.range(2**100, 2**101, 2**100)
Out[2]: range(1267650600228229401496703205376, 2535301200456458802993406410752, 1267650600228229401496703205376)
```

A possible solution is to reimplement for Py2 xrange based on itertools (something like `islice(count(start, step), (stop-start+step-1)//step)` but it doesn't provide `__len__`).

title: Add functions to get list of keys, values and items from dicts efficiently
body:
Originally reported by: **Antti Haapala (Bitbucket: [antti_haapala](https://bitbucket.org/antti_haapala), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

There are often cases where old Python 2 code uses `dict.keys()` to create a copy of the keys and then iterates over the copy while the original dictionary is being modified. For such cases there should be the `listkeys`, `listitems` and `listvalues` that would be mapped to `keys`, `items` and `values` on Python 2, and `list()`-wrapped versions thereof in Python 3.

title: Unable to inherit from multiple classes using six.add_metaclass
body:
Originally reported by: **Julien Danjou (Bitbucket: [jdanjou](https://bitbucket.org/jdanjou), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

The following code snippet does not work with six and should AFAIU.

```
#!python

import six

class MetaA(type): pass
class MetaB(type): pass
class MetaC(MetaA, MetaB): pass

class A(object):
    __metaclass__ = MetaA

class B(object):
    __metaclass__ = MetaB

class C(A, B):
    __metaclass__ = MetaC

# Six version
@six.add_metaclass(MetaA)
class A(object): pass

@six.add_metaclass(MetaB)
class B(object): pass

class MetaC(MetaA, MetaB): pass

# This fails
@six.add_metaclass(MetaC)
class C(A, B): pass
```

title: Deprecate exec_
body:
Originally reported by: **Antti Haapala (Bitbucket: [antti_haapala](https://bitbucket.org/antti_haapala), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

Deprecate exec_; it is unnecessary, considering that exec(code, globals, locals) is supported in all python versions: http://stackoverflow.com/q/12809234/918959. 

Furthermore no double-exec hacks are needed in exec_

```
#!python

    def exec_(_code_, _globs_=None, _locs_=None):
        """Execute code in a namespace."""
        if _globs_ is None:
            frame = sys._getframe(1)
            _globs_ = frame.f_globals
            if _locs_ is None:
                _locs_ = frame.f_locals
            del frame
        elif _locs_ is None:
            _locs_ = _globs_
        exec(_code_, _globs_, _locs_)
```

title: `print_` and builtin `print` behave differently
body:
Originally reported by: **Jim Witschey (Bitbucket: [mambocab](https://bitbucket.org/mambocab), GitHub: [mambocab](https://github.com/mambocab))**

----------------------------------------

As shown [here](https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/src/784c6a213c4527ea18f86a800f51bf16bc1df5bc/six.py?at=default#cl-725), `print_('foo', file=None)` will do nothing and return immediately. As documented [here](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#print), Python 3's `print` and `__future__`'s `print_function`, given the same arguments, will default to `sys.stdout`.

I think `print_`'s behavior should either be the same as the `print` function in this regard, or documented as being different. Happy to file a PR if the maintainers think this should be fixed.

title: Copying sys.meta_path can fail on six._SixMetaPathImporter
body:
Originally reported by: **marmaduke woodman (Bitbucket: [maedoc](https://bitbucket.org/maedoc), GitHub: [maedoc](https://github.com/maedoc))**

----------------------------------------

When deepcopying `sys.meta_path` after six is imported, deepcopy ends up trying to copy stuff like ZMQ sockets when used in IPython, because six's `_SixMetaPathImporter` is in the `meta_path`. I haven't take time to understand why this happens but rather set up a [workaround in our application](https://github.com/the-virtual-brain/tvb-library/blob/trunk/tvb/basic/profile.py#L55) by registering a `_SixMetaPathImporter` specific serializer in the `copy_reg` module, but it could be nice to see it in six so that others don't run into this problem.

If interested I can submit appropriate pull request to six.

title: Improve int2byte() performance on Python 3
body:
Originally reported by: **Wouter Bolsterlee (Bitbucket: [wbolster](https://bitbucket.org/wbolster), GitHub: [wbolster](https://github.com/wbolster))**

----------------------------------------

Current PY3 implementation:

```
#!python
    if sys.version_info[1] <= 1:
        def int2byte(i):
            return bytes((i,))
    else:
        # This is about 2x faster than the implementation above on 3.2+
        int2byte = operator.methodcaller("to_bytes", 1, "big")
```

I found a third approach that's even faster than the above:

```
#!python
def int2byte_alt(i, _tbl=bytes(range(256))):
    return _tbl[i:i+1]
```

It behaves the same way:

```
#!python
>>> [int2byte(i) for i in range(256)] == [int2byte_alt(i) for i in range(256)]
True
```

Let's benchmark:

```
>>> import operator
>>> import sys
>>> sys.version
'3.4.2 (default, Oct 19 2014, 17:55:38) \n[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 6.0 (clang-600.0.54)]'
>>> int2byte = operator.methodcaller("to_bytes", 1, "big")
>>> def int2byte_alt(i, _tbl=bytes(range(256))): return _tbl[i:i+1]
```

Current implementation:

```
#!python
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 418 ns per loop
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 344 ns per loop
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 392 ns per loop
```

Proposed alternative:

```
#!python
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte_alt(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 316 ns per loop
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte_alt(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 291 ns per loop
>>> %timeit -r 10 int2byte_alt(123)
1000000 loops, best of 10: 285 ns per loop
```

----------------------------------------

title: @six.add_metaclass and Django models
body:
Originally reported by: **sodas tsai (Bitbucket: [sodastsai](https://bitbucket.org/sodastsai), GitHub: [sodastsai](https://github.com/sodastsai))**

----------------------------------------

While making Django models with custom metaclass,
I used the decorator to keep compatibility between Python 2 and 3:

```python3
from django.db import models
from django.db.models.base import ModelBase
import six


class CustomModelBase(ModelBase):
    def __init__(cls, name, bases, attrs):
        super(CustomModelBase, cls).__init__(name, bases, attrs)
        print(name)


@six.add_metaclass(CustomModelBase)
class CustomModel(models.Model):
    some_field = models.CharField(max_length=128)

```

But while starting my Django server, I got following exceptions:
```py3tb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/__init__.py", line 21, in setup
    apps.populate(settings.INSTALLED_APPS)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/apps/registry.py", line 108, in populate
    app_config.import_models(all_models)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/apps/config.py", line 202, in import_models
    self.models_module = import_module(models_module_name)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/importlib/__init__.py", line 109, in import_module
    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2254, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2237, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2226, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1200, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1129, in _exec
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1471, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 321, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "/work/core/models/__init__.py", line 88, in <module>
    class CustomModel(models.Model):
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/six.py", line 794, in wrapper
    return metaclass(cls.__name__, cls.__bases__, orig_vars)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 168, in __new__
    new_class.add_to_class(obj_name, obj)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 297, in add_to_class
    value.contribute_to_class(cls, name)
  File "/work/venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/db/models/options.py", line 129, in contribute_to_class
    if self.meta:
AttributeError: 'Options' object has no attribute 'meta'
```

By using Python 3's metaclass syntax, the ```CustomModel``` class works correctly without such ```AttributeError```.
```python3
from django.db import models
from django.db.models.base import ModelBase


class CustomModelBase(ModelBase):
    def __init__(cls, name, bases, attrs):
        super(CustomModelBase, cls).__init__(name, bases, attrs)
        print(name)


class CustomModel(models.Model, metaclass=CustomModelBase):
    some_field = models.CharField(max_length=128)

```

It seems the decorator forgot to copy some attributes that set by Django's ```ModelBase``` metaclass.

I'm using ```Python 3.4.2```, ```six 1.9.0```, and ```Django 1.7.4``` on ```OS X 10.10.2```.

title: Enable importing from within custom renames
body:
Originally reported by: **Björn Pollex (Bitbucket: [bjoernpollex](https://bitbucket.org/bjoernpollex), GitHub: [bjoernpollex](https://github.com/bjoernpollex))**

----------------------------------------

Currently (using Python 3.4.2 and six 1.9.0) this code doesn't work:
```
#!python

from six import add_move, MovedModule
add_move(MovedModule('mock', 'mock', 'unittest.mock'))
from six.moves.mock import MagicMock
```
while this does:
```
#!python

from six import add_move, MovedModule
add_move(MovedModule('mock', 'mock', 'unittest.mock'))
from six.moves import mock
mock.MagicMock()
```
When adding a custom rename, it would be great to be able to use the same syntax as for the builtin renames. If that is not possible, then at least a note should be added to the documentation about the unintuitive (IMHO) behaviour.

ImportError exception:
**"ImportError: No module named intern"**

## Discovered with PyTools 2014.3.5 and PyOpenCL ##

PyTools (__init__.py) attempts to import intern from six.moves:

```
#!python

from six.moves import range, zip, intern, input
```

### Temporary workaround: ###
Modify PyTools (__init__.py) to try the import and catch ImportError exceptions:

e.g.

```
#!python
try:
	from six.moves import range, zip, intern, input
except ImportError:
	from six.moves import range, zip, input
```

title: Performance improvement for six.iterbytes
body:
Originally reported by: **Wouter Bolsterlee (Bitbucket: [wbolster](https://bitbucket.org/wbolster), GitHub: [wbolster](https://github.com/wbolster))**

----------------------------------------


On Python 3 `iterbytes()` function is simpliy an alias to `iter()`. On Python 2, it is currently defined like this:

```
#!python

def iterbytes(buf):
    return (ord(byte) for byte in buf)
```

An alternative implementation, which moves the looping to C code and avoids repeated lookups for the `ord` name, seems to be significantly faster:

```
#!python
import functools
import itertools

iterbytes_alternative = functools.partial(itertools.imap, ord)
```

This interactive IPython session (running Python 2.7) shows my benchmark results:

```
#!python
>>> def iterbytes(buf):
...         return (ord(byte) for byte in buf)
... 

>>> import functools
>>> import itertools
>>> iterbytes_alternative = functools.partial(itertools.imap, ord)

>>> %timeit -r5 -n 10000 for c in iterbytes(b): pass
10000 loops, best of 5: 379 µs per loop

>>> %timeit -r5 -n 10000 for c in iterbytes_alternative(b): pass
10000 loops, best of 5: 237 µs per loop
```

I'd suggest replacing the current implementation with my alternative version.

title: with_meta and stack frame issues
body:
Originally reported by: **faassen (Bitbucket: [faassen](https://bitbucket.org/faassen), GitHub: [faassen](https://github.com/faassen))**

----------------------------------------

[I also reported this issue to the python-future people, here: https://github.com/PythonCharmers/python-future/issues/75]

In Morepath, I use a library Venusian within a metaclass to attach some information. Venusian goes up the frames to find out in which context the attachment takes place (module, class).

Introducing the metaclass in Morepath broke its Python 3 compatibility. So I tried to use future.utils.with_meta. I couldn't make it work -- the depth of the stack frame had changed. I adjusted the Venusian call to use an increased depth, but from my limited debugging, the depth of the stack frame seems to vary depending on whether a class (with a metaclass) is defined in a function or in a module-level context.

I discovered future contains a copy of six. So I tried using future.utils.six's with_meta and all my tests passed without a problem in Python 2, Python 3 and PyPy. I didn't need to adjust the depth either.

To make matters more exciting, I switched to six proper, 1.7.3, which is presumably a more recent version than the copy in python-future, and all my tests broke again in a similar way to python-future's...

I thought I'd better report this problem.

Meanwhile I think it's best to take old-six's version and copy it into Morepath. I guess it isn't perfect, but it seems to work for my purposes.

It would be nice if at the very least with_meta's stack frame behavior could be made consistent all the way through. Preferably level 1 of depth like plain Python, but if it's to be 2, I can adjust for that, as long as it's the same in all circumstances and versions of Python.

I'd also like to know *why* the old version in six needed to be adjusted -- presumably it fixes some issues with metaclasses, and since the old version does the job for my metaclass, I wonder what's wrong with it and if it's going to bite me.

- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/issue/83

title: Add support for execfile
body:
Originally reported by: **Jason R. Coombs (Bitbucket: [jaraco](https://bitbucket.org/jaraco), GitHub: [jaraco](https://github.com/jaraco))**

----------------------------------------

Python 3 removes execfile. The [official recommendation](http://python3porting.com/differences.html#execfile) is to simply use:

```
exec(open(filename).read())
```

However, this technique fails on Python 3 but not on Python 2 when filename contains a Byte-Order Mark (BOM). Setuptools currently has its [own compatibility method](https://bitbucket.org/pypa/setuptools/src/b58b2771e983e372079bdf55f2ded15cd8fd7f19/setuptools/compat.py?at=default#cl-68) for execfile which protects from BOM errors by opening the file in binary mode. I note, however, that there is a bug in the setuptools implementation with the scope of 'globals'.

I suggest six should implement execfile to capture subtle nuances about encodings and any other compatibility issues that might arise in the use of execfile.

Then again, since Python 3 doesn't even have an execfile equivalent, perhaps six should simply provide a 'read_file_for_exec' method. That seems a lot more convoluted than an execfile, though.

Thoughts?

It looks like the implmention of `six.with_metaclass` has changed from
```python
def with_metaclass(meta, *bases):
    """Create a base class with a metaclass."""
    return meta("NewBase", bases, {})
```
to
```python
def with_metaclass(meta, *bases):
    """Create a base class with a metaclass."""
    # This requires a bit of explanation: the basic idea is to make a
    # dummy metaclass for one level of class instantiation that replaces
    # itself with the actual metaclass.  Because of internal type checks
    # we also need to make sure that we downgrade the custom metaclass
    # for one level to something closer to type (that's why __call__ and
    # __init__ comes back from type etc.).
    class metaclass(meta):
        __call__ = type.__call__
        __init__ = type.__init__
        def __new__(cls, name, this_bases, d):
            if this_bases is None:
                return type.__new__(cls, name, (), d)
            return meta(name, bases, d)
    return metaclass('temporary_class', None, {})
```

title: Replace the implementation of `six.with_metaclass` with the Flask one.
body:
Originally reported by: **charettes (Bitbucket: [charettes](https://bitbucket.org/charettes), GitHub: [charettes](https://github.com/charettes))**

----------------------------------------

The actual implementation of `six.with_metaclass` creates an instance of the provided `metaclass` which ends up leaving `NewBase` artefacts in the `__mro__`. Those undesirable bases can then be [a pain to deal with](https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/db/models/base.py#L71-L77).

The [nifty Flask implementation](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/blob/6ec83e18dca497a8fbfca6caca5999984bd32f2e/flask/_compat.py#L56) on the other hand does not seems to suffer from theese limitations and is BSD licensed.

I propose to replace the actual implementation by the Flask one.

title: Create six.wraps
body:
Originally reported by: **Anonymous**

----------------------------------------

The functools.wraps in py3.2+ has a '__wrapped__' attribute, to smooth over the difference between this and python2.x it would be nice to have a version of wraps() in six that adds on the '__wrapped__' for those still in py2.x.

Something like the following could be one way to do this:


```
#!python

def wraps(fn):

    def wrapper(f):
        f = functools.wraps(fn)(f)
        f.__wrapped__ = getattr(fn, '__wrapped__', fn)
        return f

    return wrapper
```

title: importing six breaks pickling
body:
Originally reported by: **Anselm Kruis (Bitbucket: [akruis](https://bitbucket.org/akruis), GitHub: [akruis](https://github.com/akruis))**

----------------------------------------

The python2.7 library module pickle contains the function whichmodule(func, funcname). This function eventually inspects every value in sys.modules, triggering imports, that might fail.

This way importing six in one module can break pickling in a completely unrelated module. 

An example trace-back on Linux:
```
  File "/scr/fg2ef/kruis/slp276/lib/python2.7/pickle.py", line 854, in whichmodule
    if name != '__main__' and getattr(module, funcname, None) is func:
  File "/scr/fg2ef/kruis/slp276_six/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py", line 116, in __getattr__
    _module = self._resolve()
  File "/scr/fg2ef/kruis/slp276_six/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py", line 105, in _resolve
    return _import_module(self.mod)
  File "/scr/fg2ef/kruis/slp276_six/lib/python2.7/site-packages/six.py", line 76, in _import_module
    __import__(name)
ImportError: No module named _winreg
```

Code of function whichmodule:
```
def whichmodule(func, funcname):
    """Figure out the module in which a function occurs.

    Search sys.modules for the module.
    Cache in classmap.
    Return a module name.
    If the function cannot be found, return "__main__".
    """
    # Python functions should always get an __module__ from their globals.
    mod = getattr(func, "__module__", None)
    if mod is not None:
        return mod
    if func in classmap:
        return classmap[func]

    for name, module in sys.modules.items():
        if module is None:
            continue # skip dummy package entries
        if name != '__main__' and getattr(module, funcname, None) is func:
            break
    else:
        name = '__main__'
    classmap[func] = name
    return name
```
Similar code exists in the C-function whichmodule of the extension module Modules/cPickle.c. Therefore it is probably impossible to fix this problem by monkey-patching the Python library.

Idea for a fix: don't populate sys.modules during the import of six itself, but use a sys.meta_path finder (see PEP302) to add six-modules on demand.

title: with_metaclass() function issue
body:
Originally reported by: **martineau2 (Bitbucket: [martineau2](https://bitbucket.org/martineau2), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

Unable to convert following relatively simple Py 2 metaclass using `six.with_metaclass()` function. Reason: class dictionary usually passed to metaclass `__new__()` does not have attributes defined in the client class definition in it.

Original Python 2.x version:
```
#!python

class AKA(type):
    """ 'Also Known As' metaclass to create aliases for a class. """
    def __new__(cls, classname, bases, attrs):
        print('in AKA.__new__')
        class_ = type(classname, bases, attrs)
        globals().update({alias: class_ for alias in attrs.get('aliases', [])})
        return class_

class C(object):
    __metaclass__ = AKA
    aliases = 'C1', 'C2'

print(C)          # <class '__main__.C'>
print(C.aliases)  # ('C1', 'C2')
print(C1)         # <class '__main__.C'>
print(C2)         # <class '__main__.C'>
```

Modifications to use `with_metaclass()`:
```
#!python

import six

class AKA(type):
    """ 'Also Known As' metaclass to create aliases for a class. """
    def __new__(cls, classname, bases, attrs):
        print('in AKA.__new__(cls={}, bases={}, attrs={})'.format(
                              cls, bases, attrs))  # display arguments passed
        class_ = type(classname, bases, attrs)
        globals().update({alias: class_ for alias in attrs.get('aliases', [])})
        return class_

class C_Base(object):
    pass

class C(six.with_metaclass(AKA, C_Base)):
    aliases = 'C1', 'C2'

# in AKA.__new__(cls=<class '__main__.AKA'>, bases=(<class '__main__.C_Base'>,), attrs={})
print(C)          # <class '__main__.C'>
print(C.aliases)  # ('C1', 'C2')
print(C1)         # NameError: name 'C1' is not defined
print(C2)         # never gets here...
```
The `with_metaclass()` version gets the error because the contents of the `attrs` dictionary passed to the metaclass `AKA.__new__()` method was empty.

I think I'm using the function in accordance with the [documentation](http://pythonhosted.org/six/#six.with_metaclass). I tried moving the definition of `aliases` from `class C` to `class C_Base` to no avail.

-- 
Martin

title: Problem Running on Google App Engine
body:
Originally reported by: **speedplane (Bitbucket: [speedplane](https://bitbucket.org/speedplane), GitHub: [speedplane](https://github.com/speedplane))**

----------------------------------------

When I upgraded to 1.5.2 I started having problems on google app engine.  I started getting errors about importing `_tkinter` and `gdbm` (this may be related to issue #54).

I think the problem is that app engine has a special module loading hook that may be somewhat incompatible with `MovedModule`.  App engine uses the `__path__` attribute when loading modules.

I think I tracked down the bug, but I'm not sure.  I modified `MovedModule.___getattr__` to also raise an `AttributeError` when checking `__path__`.  This seemed to work for me.


```
#!python
    def __getattr__(self, attr):
        # Hack around the Django autoreloader. The reloader tries to get
        # __file__ or __name__ of every module in sys.modules. This doesn't work
        # well if this MovedModule is for an module that is unavailable on this
        # machine (like winreg on Unix systems). Thus, we pretend __file__ and
        # __name__ don't exist if the module hasn't been loaded yet. See issues
        # #51 and #53.
        if attr in ("__path__", "__file__", "__name__") and self.mod not in sys.modules:
            raise AttributeError
        _module = self._resolve()
        value = getattr(_module, attr)
        setattr(self, attr, value)
        return value
```

title: six.moves.xrange name is inconsistent with six.moves naming conventions
body:
Originally reported by: **Dan Blanchard (Bitbucket: [daniel_blanchard](https://bitbucket.org/daniel_blanchard), GitHub: Unknown)**

----------------------------------------

I've recently started using six, and I noticed something really puzzling in the naming conventions for some of the functions in six.moves that have to do with generators:

filter, map, and zip are all named after the Python 3 version.
xrange is named after the Python 2 version.

Why is this the case? With the current name, using "range" in Python 2 will give you a list and in Python 3 it'll give you a range object. This makes it really easy to make mistakes by writing code with Python 2 and not having it run correctly on Python 3. If the idea is that people should get used to writing constructions like `list(range(...))`, it would make more sense if you were forced to do that instead of being able to accidentally write code that only runs on Python 2.

This issue would be entirely prevented if the name was just "range" like with "zip". With zip you also have to put an outer list to make things work as expected on Python 3, but it won't work on Python 2 either because the default "zip" is overridden.

title: Additional object model compatibility methods
body:
Originally reported by: **Aymeric Augustin (Bitbucket: [aaugustin](https://bitbucket.org/aaugustin), GitHub: [aaugustin](https://github.com/aaugustin))**

----------------------------------------

http://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.0.html?#operators-and-special-methods says:

> `func_closure`, `func_code`, `func_defaults`, `func_dict`, `func_doc`, `func_globals`, `func_name` were renamed to `__closure__`, `__code__`, `__defaults__`, `__dict__`, `__doc__`, `__globals__`, `__name__`, respectively.

Currently six only provides compatibility methods for the second and the third of these seven attributes: `get_function_code` and `get_function_defaults`.

Apparently, some of the new names already work under CPython 2.x. But they aren't documented and some alternative implementations don't have them. For instance, PyPy 1.9 doesn't have `__globals__`: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/19944

I suggest to add compatibility methods for the five other function attributes; or if there's a good reason I'm not aware of for not providing them, to explain it in the docs :)

I can fix this in the patched version of six shipped with Django (it already adds a few Django-specific compatibility functions), but since that problem isn't specific to Django, I'm filing this ticket here too.

The problem has to do with the line

which will overwrite any previously defined moves upon importing six from a separate namespace.

----------------------------------------

Hi,

We're planning to embed six in Django as the blessed Python 3 compatibility layer. One thing we're missing is a function that returns a byte string on Python 2 and Unicode in Python 3. This is typically useful when providing arguments for strftime() or type(). Our current implementation is:
* Python 2: n = lambda n: n.encode('utf-8')
* Python 3 (noop): n = lambda n: n

We could of course provide it in some of our own modules, but it would be nice to have it in six, unless you suggest a better replacement.

----------------------------------------
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/gutworth/six/issue/12

title: Jython compatibility in setup.py
body:
Originally reported by: **squeaky (Bitbucket: [squeaky](https://bitbucket.org/squeaky), GitHub: [squeaky](https://github.com/squeaky))**

----------------------------------------

Jython internally uses Java Integer type which is 32bit on the JVM regardless of the CPU for Python int representation. Jython also requires
__len__ to return an Python integer and not long. The following code breaks on Jython because it returns Python long.
    
    class X(object):
            def __len__(self):
                return 1 << 31
        try:
            len(X())
        except OverflowError:
            # 32-bit
            MAXSIZE = int((1 << 31) - 1)
    
    

because __len__ returns Python long.

    
    
    except (OverflowError, TypeError):
    
    

fixes the issue.

See https://bitbucket.org/squeaky/six/changeset/05d26f6faf8f

title: Script to “six-ify” source
body:
Originally reported by: **Zearin (Bitbucket: [Zearin](https://bitbucket.org/Zearin), GitHub: [Zearin](https://github.com/Zearin))**

----------------------------------------

**Wouldn’t it be cool if six had a script in the spirit of `2to3`?  **

Imagine if this (invented) example were possible:
    
    $ python -m "six" spam.py eggs.py food/*.py
    
    …Adding "import six" to source…
    Success!
    
    …Converting "isinstance" and "issubclass" to six constants for:
        …six.class_types…
        Success!
        
        …six.integer_types…
        Success!
        
        …six.string_types…
        Success!
    
    …Converting "print" to "six.print_"…
        Success on 38 of 40 occurrences; couldn’t convert the following:
        
        spam.py:135 : Ambiguous print arguments.  Please fix manually.
        spam.py:202 : Ambiguous print arguments.  Please fix manually.
        
        Comments labelled "# @SIXME" have been inserted to mark these locations.
    
    

---- 

**Basically:**

Six is awesome, and there are plenty of cases where existing could needs the scrutiny of a human to determine how to integrate six.  But there are plenty of cases where it’s a no-brainer: 

* uses of `isinstance` or `issubclass`
* `print`
* module renames (as seen in //[[http://packages.python.org/six/#module-six.moves|Renamed modules and attributes compatibility]]// of the documentation.) 

Following `2to3`’s example, the script should allow fine-grained control to opt-in or opt-out of any particular conversions.

title: map/filter issues
body:
Originally reported by: **Michael Salib (Bitbucket: [msalib](https://bitbucket.org/msalib), GitHub: [msalib](https://github.com/msalib))**

----------------------------------------

Right now, I'm having trouble with map/filter in code that is supposed to run under 2.x and 3.x. I try to use from future_builtins import map, filter but py3 doesn't have a future_builtins module. I propose that six add MovedAttributes for both map and filter, using the itertools version in py2.x (which is what the future_builtins versions actually are anyway...) and the standard builtins version in py3.x. I've attached a patch that makes this change and adds tests; my patch also adds py32 to the tox environment list and adds .tox to .hgignore for convenience.

Thanks!

title: u() function does not support unicode character escapes
body:
Originally reported by: **Matt Chaput (Bitbucket: [mchaput](https://bitbucket.org/mchaput), GitHub: [mchaput](https://github.com/mchaput))**

----------------------------------------

If I do:

    
    six.u("\u1234")
    

in Python 2.x I should get:

    
    u'\u1234'
    

but instead I get:

    
    u'\\uABCD'
    

Unfortunately the only way I can think of to fix this is to loop through the unicode string with a regular expression and rebuild the string to replace `\\u([0-9a-fA-F]{4})` with `unichr(int(match.group(1), 16))` if you see what I mean.
